channel.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
channel.description:
I needs help with loading Client on my Mac OSX
EDIT: Mac is a linux.
I get this error when i attempt to run my client
[code]Macintosh-2:~ tempjoes$ java /Users/tempjoes/Desktop/St/RMScape/Client/EGUI.class Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: /Users/tempjoes/Desktop/St/RMScape/Client/EGUI/class [/code]
Does anyone know what this means & how you fix it?

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:21, topic:294173”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=389094.msg2917639#msg2917639 date=1250553944]
Another thing that breaks cross platform compatibility is case-sensitivity. Windows, regardless of the file system it runs on, ignores case.
[/quote]
not true. i have an ext2 drive that i access from windows and it is case sensitive[/quote]

NTFS is a file system that supports case-sensitivity, when you access it from linux for example, but not from windows.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:20, topic:294173”]I also believe that ‘\’ also works on all systems.[/quote]No it doesn’t. It did not work on my linux partition (distro is ubuntu):

[quote=“xeez`, post:15, topic:294173”][code]import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.File;

public class Test
{
public static void main(String[] argv) {
try
{
BufferedImage img = ImageIO.read(new File(".\test.png"));
} catch(Exception e)
{
e.printStackTrace();
}
}
}[/code]
Throws a file not found exception.

EDIT: Read your edit. Told ya :P[/quote]Moparisthebest, I agree on many of the things you stated, but keep in mind, that wasn’t the topic we were discussing. We were discussing whether these “flaws” which limit an application to work on specific systems, is a “flaw” from the Java I/O API itself, or the programmer’s. I had said programmer’s, while Unhandled and Mopman had said API’s.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Another thing that breaks cross platform compatibility is case-sensitivity. Windows, regardless of the file system it runs on, ignores case.

not true. i have an ext2 drive that i access from windows and it is case sensitive

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I have programmed many programs in java (and other programming languages, but we will ignore those for now) that work in multiple operating systems.

The separator ‘/’ works on all systems, I also believe that ‘\’ also works on all systems.

The things that break cross platform compatibility are stupid things that some people do, like ‘~/somefile’ will only work on unix systems, and ‘C:\somefile’ will only work on windows systems (and further only on windows systems with a C: drive, which not all of them have one)

Another thing that breaks cross platform compatibility is case-sensitivity. Windows, regardless of the file system it runs on, ignores case. To windows, ‘bob’ is the same as ‘BoB’ or ‘Bob’, whereas linux running on a case-sensitive filesystem (most of them) sees those same strings as 3 different files. You can see the havoc that inevitably results. (the same thing applies on other programming languages, I remember in my opengl class the teacher’s example programs never ran until I lower-cased all of the file strings, it was a pain in my ass, don’t do it.)

In conclusion, when programming java use ‘/’ as a file separator and use all lowercase files and strings (or at least be consistent in code and on the file).

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:18, topic:294173”][quote author=xeez` link=topic=389094.msg2915762#msg2915762 date=1250391745]
To make this clearer, an example: a file on UNIX which contains the character ‘’ (backslash), does not imply that it is referring to a directory, rather than just part of the file name, whereas on a Windows system it does. Like this, there are many examples.
[/quote]

I understand the issue. I still say its an API issue.[/quote]Do you have the same opinion concerning system calls? Do you think java should restrict programmers to use system commands that are compatible with all platforms? Obviously not. Because this issue is strictly platform-dependent. Same with file directories.

Keep in mind, this is only my opinion. Many people (like you) will beg to differ.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

xeez`:

To make this clearer, an example: a file on UNIX which contains the character ‘’ (backslash), does not imply that it is referring to a directory, rather than just part of the file name, whereas on a Windows system it does. Like this, there are many examples.

I understand the issue. I still say its an API issue.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:16, topic:294173”]If java were truly cross platform, shouldn’t it just abstract from all that… (more than providing File.separator)[/quote]I assume it should, but they can’t be as stringent with file-interaction, which basically depends on the string passed as directory, on the same level on every single system.

To make this clearer, an example: a file on UNIX which contains the character ‘’ (backslash), does not imply that it is referring to a directory, rather than just part of the file name, whereas on a Windows system it does. Like this, there are many examples.

Many things in Java are abstract for the language’s programmer concerning cross-platform issues. Such as memory handling, external connections, etc.

Sun tries to make Java be as flexible as it can be, while maintaining platform-independency; but at the end of the day, it is in the hand’s of the programmer.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:10, topic:294173”]That shouldn’t stop it working on linux, unless the java IO api is really that bad[/quote]It actually does. Unless you use something like: [tt]java.io.File.separator[/tt], it will not run.

Actually, it has nothing to do with the I/O API, as it clearly includes the necessary resources to make the code portable. It’s the programmer that is really bad.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:8, topic:294173”]Macs are also based on BSD(well, mine is at least). Linux is not. And that error means it couldn’t find the class. If it’s used in a package system, like org.zephyrion.oraculum, and the org directory is in the src directory, you would cd to src, and compile from there, using tha fully annotated class name. However, since it seems you’re just using a standard client, you have to do this:

cd; cd Desktop/St/RMScape*/Client; java EGUI;

And private servers are NOT limited to work only with windows. Are you shortbus? Java is platform independent, meaning that if it can be written on one system, it can be ran on another(assuming the java versions are compatible || backwards compatible).[/quote]You clearly do not understand that one can limit an application written in a language that is compatible with diverse OS’, like java, to run on a single OS, by things that would seem meaningless. For example, an application that loads an image, as so:

ImageIO.read(new File("dir\\image")); would disable the application from running on a linux operating system. So yes, even though java is cross-platform, it does not mean that applications that are horribly programmed (like the few private servers’ clients I have seen) will be cross-platform.

Read full topic

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Macs are also based on BSD(well, mine is at least). Linux is not. And that error means it couldn’t find the class. If it’s used in a package system, like org.zephyrion.oraculum, and the org directory is in the src directory, you would cd to src, and compile from there, using tha fully annotated class name. However, since it seems you’re just using a standard client, you have to do this:

cd; cd Desktop/St/RMScape*/Client; java EGUI;

And private servers are NOT limited to work only with windows. Are you shortbus? Java is platform independent, meaning that if it can be written on one system, it can be ran on another(assuming the java versions are compatible || backwards compatible).

Read full topic

Its also a linux. Debian mostly. Unix too.[/quote]

OSX is not Linux, it uses the XNU kernel. It also has nothing to do with Debian.

item.title: Help with Linux/MacOS Client Loading
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

When running the JVM through JDK’s “java” application, it assumes that any “dot” (.) refers to specific package names. With this in mind, it interprets the directory: “/Users/tempjoes/Desktop/St/RMScape/Client/EGUI.class” as “/Users/tempjoes/Desktop/St/RMScape/Client/EGUI/class”. As you can see, it interpreted “EGUI” as a directory rather than the actual file name. Instead of passing the class name (EGUI) along with the file format (.class), you simply pass the class’ name. So to run it, you’d do:

java /Users/tempjoes/Desktop/St/RMScape/Client/EGUI

Just a fore-warning: Most current runescape private server’s clients are limited to work only within windows due to the faulty programming.

EDIT: Off topic: Is your PC anything other than a macintosh? If so, I’d like to know how you managed to install the OSX, seeing as Apple restricts most/all of their software to work only with their hardware.

Read full topic
